item.title: Daniela Serrano - 2016-04-24 01:48:15
item.content:encoded:
Hello,
My name is Daniela, I am a student at the University of North Texas. My major is anthropology and I am currently enrolled in a class called people of South Asia. We were assigned a project in which we have to explore the migration of people from South Asia in the DFW region. We also had a book project, my book was called "In My Mother's House," written by Sharika Thiranagama. It is about the Sri Lankan civil war so that is why I chose this temple, in order to learn more about one of the many religions in Sri Lanka. I was wondering if I could have the permission to visit this Temple, get a tour and interview a representative about the history of the Temple and more information about the people the Temple serves. Thank you, Daniela <!--more--> AUTHOR: Daniela Serrano AUTHOR EMAIL: danielaserrano@my.unt.edu AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: Contact form submitted through dfwbuddhist.com IP: 108.162.221.231 Array ( [1_Name] => Daniela Serrano [2_Email] => danielaserrano@my.unt.edu [3_Phone] => [4_Comment] => Hello,
My name is Daniela, I am a student at the University of North Texas. My major is anthropology and I am currently enrolled in a class called people of South Asia. We were assigned a project in which we have to explore the migration of people from South Asia in the DFW region. We also had a book project, my book was called "In My Mother's House," written by Sharika Thiranagama. It is about the Sri Lankan civil war so that is why I chose this temple, in order to learn more about one of the many religions in Sri Lanka. I was wondering if I could have the permission to visit this Temple, get a tour and interview a representative about the history of the Temple and more information about the people the Temple serves. Thank you, Daniela [5_Signup for temple newsletters] => Yes )

Just for reference you can see our recent work here: http://webtrafficpros.info/#portfolio

Custom Web Development and Software Programming Building New Websites with Custom Features Building & Maintaining E-commerce Websites Fixing bad code and security issues. Optimizing sites for Google, Bing and Yahoo Web Design, Server Management and more.
I personally have more than 10 years of Logo Designing and web development experience under my belt and look forward to helping you with any updates or website issues that may need our expert assistance with.

item.title: Darlene Will - 2016-06-02 15:17:38
item.content:encoded: I am a social worker at JPS Hospital in Ft. Worth. We have a family of Vietnamese origin and of the Buddhist faith. Due to a serious health concern within the family they are struggling emotionally and asking for spiritual support from someone of their faith background. This is an urgent matter. Could someone from your center please call me ASAP and let me know if you can provide support for this family or direct me where to go. Thank you for your prompt reply. <!--more--> AUTHOR: Darlene Will AUTHOR EMAIL: DWill01@jpshealth.org AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: Contact form submitted through dfwbuddhist.com IP: 108.162.238.165 Array ( [1_Name] => Darlene Will [2_Email] => DWill01@jpshealth.org [3_Phone] => 214-215-4685 [4_Comment] => I am a social worker at JPS Hospital in Ft. item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded:
Theruwan Saranai

Welcome to the DFW Buddhist Vihara (Texas Buddhist Meditation Center). We are a Sri Lankan Theravada Buddhist temple located in Fort Worth, Texas, serving all in the DFW area. We organize meditationand dhamma classes as well as various community events. A place toappreciate Sri Lankan culture while taking steps in the path of dhamma.

item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [contact-field label='Name' type='name' required='1'/][contact-field label='Email' type='email' required='1'/][contact-field label='Phone' type='text'/][contact-field label='Comment' type='textarea' required='1'/][contact-field label='Signup for temple newsletters' type='checkbox'/]

item.title: Buddha
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara

item.title: Dhamma
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Below are some valuable links to find out more about Dhamma. Tripitaka Pirith Amarawathi Buddhist Monastery Godwin Seeing through the net Buddhist Publication Society ForestSangha Pariyatti Kauffman Vipassana Meditation Center

item.title: Sangha
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded:
Thawalama Punnaji thero

Born April 1st 1971 in Hiniduma in the district of Galle, Sri Lanka and received primary education at Thawalama Vidyaraja Central College. Ordained on November 16th 1980 as a student of Ven. Galle Gnanabasa thero of Weliwatta Vijayananda piriwena in Galle. Soon afterwards he entered the Diwulapitiya Balagalla Saraswathi piriwena and completed Praacheena Prarambha exam certifications. He received higher education at Kubalwella Rewatha Vidyayathana piriwena, and later received an external degree at Ruhunu University. Afterwards, he spent some time residing at the Penang Mahindarama temple in Malaysia. Punnaji thero has been the head monk at DFW Buddhist Vihara since its inception in 2008. He has worked tirelessly to create the atmosphere we currently enjoy at our temple.

Muruthawela Gnanasena

Gnanasena thero has been a residing monk at the temple since 2015. He takes part in organizing all temple events and conducts paali and dhamma classes for students of all ages.

item.title: Temple
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: DFW Buddhist Vihara (Texas Buddhist Meditation Center) was inaugurated October 5th 2008 as a non-profit organization with the sole purpose of directing people in the path of Dhamma. Since inception the templehas been providing an invaluable service to the Sri Lankan Buddhist community ofthe Dallas Fort Worth metroplex. TBMC is an integral part of annual Buddhist festivals such as Vesak, Poson and Katina. Large number of Buddhists congregate at the temple during these festivals times. Amongst the most noteworthy activities of last year includedthe chanting of Pirith with the decorated Pirith Mandapaya for 8 hours at the Katina ceremony. Ven. Punnaji Thero and other monks are always available for your religious needs at any time. Whether it is a dhaana at your house, transferring merit to relatives, or celebrating your birthday, TBMC fulfills your requests following the Theravada norms. The temple is run solely on kind donations of the devotees. Our primary mission is to guide allin the path ofDhamma. Our vision is to bring the Sri Lankan community together whiletranscending religious and cultural boundaries.

item.title: Finances
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Coming soon.

item.title: Meditation classes
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Meditation classesare monthly in the form of a retreatat the temple premises. Please refer to theevents schedulefor class times. If you are interested in participating please contact the temple for more information. You can also follow us on Facebook for upcoming retreats. Below is the format of the program. 9:00 - 11:30 Silent meditation(walking, sitting and metta) 11:30 - 12:30 Lunch break (you are welcome to bring a dish to share with the other participants) 12:30 - 1:00 Discussion on our practice of the Dhamma 1:00 - 3:00 Discussion on the Satipatthana Sutta from Bhikku

item.title: Dhamma school
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Dhamma schoolisheld on Sundays from 10am to 1pm at the temple premises for the benefit of the younger generation. Please refer to the events schedule for class times. For more information regarding the Dhamma school,please contact the temple. You can also follow us on Facebook for upcoming classes and events.

item.title: Paali classes
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Paali classes are held every fortnight on Friday 8pm at the temple premises. Classes are conducted by Ven. Muruthawela Gnanasena thero. If you are interested in participating please contact the temple for more information. You can also follow us on Facebook for upcoming classes and events. Note: If you are unable to attend the class in person, you can join the classroom via Skype.

item.title: Special events
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Pleasefollow us onFacebookfor upcoming events and activities.

item.title: Dhaana signup
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Please use the link below to sign up for daily almsgiving contributions to the Sangha. Click here to sign up

item.title: Utility bill signup
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Please contact the templeif you would like to contribute to help pay for the temple utility bills.

item.title: Donate Online
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded:
DFW Buddhist Vihara is a reflection of your generosity. The temple is run solely on kind donations by generous devotees like you. Gifts of all sizes help to ensure that our temple remain a relevant, vital and celebrated community resource for all. You can become an active member of the temple by pledging to make your donation an ongoing monthly contribution. Remember toclick on"Make this recurring" checkbox on the PayPal donation page. Please follow the link below to make your online donations via Paypal. We really appreciate your kindness and may the triple gem bless you.
** Notethat all donations to the temple are tax deductible. Once your donation is completed, you will receive an email confirmation receipt from the temple acknowledging your contribution.

item.title: Volunteering
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded:
Volunteers are an essential part of DFW Buddhist Vihara's success,and a reflection of Sri Lankan culture. One of the best ways to support our temple is to volunteer your time. There are a variety of opportunities to accommodate your interests and schedule. Below are some activities that you can participate.
  • Special event volunteering
  • Dhammaschool
  • Temple maintenance
  • Temple landscaping and upkeep

item.title: Sponsors
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: You can advertise your business here for a small fee that would go towards temple expenses. This will help you reach a large Sri Lankan community while at the same time taking part in a meritorious deed. Please contact us for more information.

item.title: Katina ceremony on November 21st
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded:
Katina ceremony at DFW Buddhist vihara will be held on November 21st 2015 at the temple premises. We are expecting about 25 monks to participate and an overnight pirith sermon. You can sign up for contributions using the sign up sheet. You may read about the merits of participating in this ceremony below.
Katina refers to the offering of the special robe (Katina sivara) prepared and presented to monks who have completed the three month period of retreat called Vas in Sinhala, and Vassana in Pali, meaning the period of rain. Katina literally means firm, or solid, because the offering of a Katina robe helps to earn solid good karma. The Katina Ceremony is over 2500 years old. It is a monastic tradition preserved and observed by Buddhists all over the world because it is an extraordinary opportunity to acquire merit once a year. The Katina robe is significant because during the three-month Vas period, Buddhist monks are required to remain fully dedicated to purifying themselves through the rigorous practice of meditation and moral conduct. As the monks end the retreat and come back to society, they become deservedly worthy of offering and veneration as punnakkhetta or field of merit to the fullest extent possible. A robe offered to such a monk potent with spirituality and dedication to religious living at this time, helps one to earn solid merit or good karma. The offering of the Katina robe is considered immensely meritorious since it involves three months of preparation and dedication. The ceremony become important and meritorious because of the potency of the merit gathered during the period of retreat, both by the monks and the devotees. The Katina robe is symbolizes the successful culmination of the rainy retreat. The main event in the Katina ceremony is the offering of the special robe known as the Katina-civara to the Sangha. This ceremony is meant to be performed with devotion and is an occasion of religious significance for Buddhists all over the world. Offering of the Katina robe started during the time of the Buddha. A group of monks went to a place for retreat. At the conclusion of the retreat they returned to visit the Buddha. On the way they were caught in a heavy downpour of rain and one monk got more wet than the others. The Buddha seeing this monk, advised the monk to accept an extra robe as a Katina. The extra robe was always given to the one who needed it the most. There are many traditions and rituals of offering a piece of cloth to monks in the name of Katina. Katina is the most significant merit making ceremony performed by Buddhist communities in Sri Lanka, Thailand, Burma, Laos and Cambodia. Vas is also the time for lay Buddhists to express their devotion and practice generosity by providing their temples with the requisites for maintaining the temples and the inhabitant monks. It is an important period for gathering merit for both the layman and the monks. During this period devotees are given the opportunity to learn the Dharma from the monks by listening to sermons, getting involved in dhamma discussions, participating in meditation programs, and listening to pirith chanting. It is a time to get blessings for good living by performing and participating in religious ceremonies. Monks help the community to lead a pure life, emphasizing the importance of practicing the Five Precepts and teachings of the Buddha. More significantly Vas is a time to strengthen ties and form bonds between monks and the laity. As spiritual leaders, monks guide the lay people towards ways of resolving problems with compassion and understanding, thereby forming strong bonds with the community. Monks dwelling in one place during Vas have more time to communicate with the laity on a one to one basis. They get the opportunity to listen to the problems of the laity and provide solutions to live a stress free life. For the above-mentioned reasons, the offering of the Katina robe is considered one of the greatest meritorious deeds. Whatever else is offered to a monk on Katina day is also considered meritorious on this special day. It is even said that one who offers a Katina robe, to a monk who has observed the spiritual guidance given by the Buddha with diligence and commitment, even on a single occasion in his lifetime, would in samsara when he is born over and over again-never be in want or destitution and never to be reduced to rags for want of clothes.
Source: http://www.buddhistvihara.com/news/what_is_katina_ritual.pdf

item.title: Sri Lankan Food Fair 2016
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Dear Friends, We are planning to have a Sri Lankan Food Fair on Saturday 30th January 2016, as a fund raiser to help pay for the temple property taxes. Please take part in this meritorious deed by attending the food fair, and your generous donations to keep our doors open. You can also volunteer to bring a food item using the sign-up sheet. Please give us a call if you have any questions regarding this event. Temple phone # (682) 316-3001 Punnaji Thero phone # (817) 449-6266 With Metta, DFW Buddhist Vihara

item.title: Event Schedule
item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded: Download PDF

item.dc:creator: kwickramasekara
item.content:encoded:
Dear Devotees,
The DFW Buddhist Vihara (TBMC) will conduct a religious program on Saturday, March 19th from 10am to 5Pm.
There will be a Meditation program which will be conducted in English by Ken Goldberg (Mediation Teacher)
Program for the day
10am - 11.30 pm Observe Ata Sil, Buddha Pooja, Dhamma Discussion.
11.45 am Alms giving to Maha Sanga, Upasaka, Upasika
12 pm - 1 pm Lunch
1 pm -2pm - by Ken Goldberg Guided meditations-on breathing, walking and loving kindness
2pm - 3:30 pm - by Ken Goldberg Dhamma talk about Meditation followed by Dhamma discussion
3:30pm -4pm - by Ken Goldberg Guided mediation
4 pm - 5 pm Dhamma Talk in Sinhala by Ven. Medamahanuwara Samithasiri Thero.
Please bring flowers, incense sticks and candles for the Buddha Pooja.
Please forward this email to all your friends who are willing to participate.

Medamahanuwara Samithasiri Thero. Please bring flowers, incense sticks and candles for the Buddha Pooja. Please forward this to all your friends who are willing to participate. The address of the Temple - 11209 Brownfield Rd, Fort Worth, TX 76028
